author: jgm

Obviously I'm not a core dev, but from an outside perspective I would hope that the plan would be to continue with the current timeline but extend the testing as much as possible in the time remaining, with the aim of increasing test coverage as much as possible.

author: 0xsadcat
content:
a consensus difference between geth and others on mainnet would be a non-event now. looking at https://www.ethernodes.org/ geth is ~90% of mainnet nodes (including erigon here). on mainnet, at least 85% of miners run mev-geth https://dashboard.flashbots.net/network. from what I know that excludes ethermine, so if ethermine is also running geth, it may be that <1% of hashrate is running openethereum, which wouldn't be that surprising as openethereum is being abandoned after london - can as well switch now.
this means that unless a consensus bug crashes geth, or breaks something very fundamental like allowing people to print eth, it wouldn't be actually dangerous and could be fixed in a soft-fork.

author: sky.cactus
content: Consensus forks and execution forks are separate.  In some cases, they will happen at the same time (when we need to update both at the same time) but it is possible for each to be on its own fork cadence.

author: .vbuterin
content: It's probably better for them to be at the same time, to reduce the number of mandatory software updates for users and validators

author: sky.cactus
content: I think we should do the other way around.  Execution client updates should move to spec-based process like consensus client updates do, not that consensus client updates should move to the EIP process like execution clients.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would hate to delay consensus updates because execution client teams are struggling to get work done or vice versa.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, you are right that the burden of updating infrastructure is non-zero and should be considered.

author: .vbuterin
content: How is that fundamentally different from delaying EIP XXX because of delays in EIP YYY in the same fork?

author: sky.cactus
content: I *think* because the failure domains are more cleanly separated.

author: sky.cactus
content: Though, I can see how that argument is kind of weak now that I say it out loud.

author: pietjepuk
content: It does make some sense though. Layer 2 protocol updates don't follow hard fork cadence either. I do feel the execution and consensus layers are (to some degree) separable concerns.

author: .vbuterin
content: My concern is that if validators are forced to get off their butts and download updates 2N times per year instead of N times, that increases the risk that they'll get lazy and just use a stake pool

author: jgm
content: Alternatively, if N is large enough they will automate the process (or _someone_ will automate the process) and it will decrease the risk.  Having `geth` on ubuntu available through `apt` is a good example of this, where updates are usually automatic and unattended.

author: .vbuterin
content: Automated updates are themselves a really politically risky concept

author: jgm
content: I think the difference we're talking is in terms of mechanics of the upgrade rather than acceptance of the change.  It's relatively unlikely that someone with even just a single validator will pay no attention to a controversial change, and so will be able to make their informed decision.  But I don't think that optimising for the expected path (and reducing the burden of decentralisation for its users) is a terrible way to go.

author: .vbuterin
content: I feel like the ethereum community is already too dangerously close to a default-to-accept mindset in a lot of levels; you don't want pressure of laziness to be *in favor* of potentially controversial changes

author: jgm
content:
I guess that depends on how wide you cast the "community" net.  We've seen a lot of discussion around EIP-1559, to take a recent example.

And given that it's incredibly rare for an upgrade to be optional, it seems that at the point the upgrade is implemented in released code is far too late to have any sort of meaningful discussion.
